Award.AwardTitle: The Long-Term Regional Economic Impacts from Public Investment in University Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project creates a new database of county-level productivity of manufacturing firms from 1947 to 1992. These historical data have been published in the Manufacturing Census reports, but are not yet electronically available. This data-collection project offers the first electronically-available information on U.S. manufacturing at the county level over a fairly long period of time. Data on 24 industries, across roughly 3,143 counties, over 10 Manufacturing Census years (1947, 1954, 1958, 1963, 1967, 1972, 1977, 1982, 1987, and 1992) yields 754,320 county-industry-year observations of cost, quantity, and productivity.

The investigators' ultimate goal is to construct a body of data that will enable them to examine how publicly-funded scientific knowledge flows across locations, and how these knowledge flows affect the development of regional economies -- thus advancing the understanding of the returns to public investment in scientific university research. The data collected under the auspices of this grant will facilitate a study of how investments in Cold-War and Space Race-era science impacted regional economies from 1947 to 1992. Research into this important historical episode in the ascendency of the modern American research university (and a period of overall economic growth for the nation, punctuated by economic and political crises) will help to uncover the extent to which the broad economic effects of public investment in university science last for many decades or are simply transitory. Through documenting changes over time in cost, efficiency, and productivity, the data will also help to shed light on the channels through which university knowledge benefits the private manufacturing sector.

Broader impacts: The panel database on the productivity of American manufacturers in the Cold War and Space Race periods is useful to a wide range of scholars interested in the direct and indirect impacts of science and technology policy at the local level and in the path of U.S. economic development more generally. The research will extend a database on the economics of American research universities developed under prior NSF support to provide an inventory of scientific capital and personnel at each university and thus an estimate of the historical capacity of these universities to absorb new scientific funding. The need to generate a consistent panel of industry-county data provides financial support for an undergraduate research assistant.

Institution.Name: National Bureau of Economic Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NATIONAL BUREAU OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: National Bureau of Economic Research Inc

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to create datasets that will enable the co-PIs to examine the role that knowledge production and dissemination from research universities play in regional economic growth. The main database that was created documents local-level productivity of manufacturing industries from 1947 to 2012. These historical data have been published in the Manufacturing Census reports, but those data prior to 1982 are not electronically available. A major task of the project was the collection, computer coding, and compilation of Census of Manufacturing data at the state, county, and city levels.

A second dataset created during the course of the project was the collection, computer coding, and compilation of data from the American Society of Engineering Education (1951). This data source provides an inventory of scientific capital and personnel at each university in 1951. These data will be used to help identify the capacity for various universities to take on the great research demands associated with the Space Race era.

A third dataset is a description of the research activities and financial condition of agricultural experiment stations from 1890 to 1973 (financials) or 1890 to 1940 (research). These data are being used to understand the localized productivity effects of university agricultural research on local farmers.

Finally, a fourth dataset describes the state of the higher education industry from 1880 to present. A prior NSF grant enabled the co-PIs to collect and code U.S. Bureau of Education data describing individual colleges and universities from 1880 to 1914. Under the auspices of the current grant, we have pushed the data collection from the Bureau of Education to 1940, when it ceased to be published. The U.S. Department of Education resumed its survey of higher education institutions in 1968.  The privately published College Blue Book reported statistical data describing colleges and universities during the 1940 to 1968 period.  Once asembled the cleaned dataset will be able to provide the first detailed statistical look at the higher education sector for over 100 years.


Last Modified: 10/11/2016
Modified by: Shawn Kantor
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of the project was to create datasets that will enable the co-PIs to examine the role that knowledge production and dissemination from research universities play in regional economic growth. The main database that was created documents local-level productivity of manufacturing industries from 1947 to 2012. These historical data have been published in the Manufacturing Census reports, but those data prior to 1982 are not electronically available. A major task of the project was the collection, computer coding, and compilation of Census of Manufacturing data at the state, county, and city levels. A second dataset created during the course of the project was the collection, computer coding, and compilation of data from the American Society of Engineering Education (1951). This data source provides an inventory of scientific capital and personnel at each university in 1951. These data will be used to help identify the capacity for various universities to take on the great research demands associated with the Space Race era. A third dataset is a description of the research activities and financial condition of agricultural experiment stations from 1890 to 1973 (financials) or 1890 to 1940 (research). These data are being used to understand the localized productivity effects of university agricultural research on local farmers. Finally, a fourth dataset describes the state of the higher education industry from 1880 to present. A prior NSF grant enabled the co-PIs to collect and code U.S. Bureau of Education data describing individual colleges and universities from 1880 to 1914. Under the auspices of the current grant, we have pushed the data collection from the Bureau of Education to 1940, when it ceased to be published. The U.S. Department of Education resumed its survey of higher education institutions in 1968. The privately published College Blue Book reported statistical data describing colleges and universities during the 1940 to 1968 period. Once asembled the cleaned dataset will be able to provide the first detailed statistical look at the higher education sector for over 100 years. Last Modified: 10/11/2016 Submitted by: Shawn Kantor
